Description: Body sherd of Laconian pottery kylix; dull cream slip; interior glazed (fired brown) with three lines in added red; exterior: reserved at junction of rim and body; below, narrow red band between two black lines; in handle zone. painted decoration consisting of frieze of geese to right (one complete with tail feathers in red; red tail feathers of second remaining); below, red band.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd probably belongs to the same vase as Bristol H4621. Attributable to the Painter of the Taranto Fish. This sherd finds parallels with a cup with conical foot in Queensland (Stibbe, 'Laconian Drinking Vases and other Open Shapes', 1994, Allard Pierson Series, p. 63, 167, pl. 12, no. 1-2).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GC.56) (phase 3)
